comments.commentBody: Thank the unions for that sense of entitlement!
Uh, no, public employee unions are as liberal as it gets! Three guesses who the police and fire unions backed in the NY mayoral race.

Everyone is on it and it was no secret. The clerks and other peripheral people knew but not directly benefited. But maybe they benefited in an oblique way. But no matter what, no once raised any flags as this had been going on before 1988?  I am sure someone had the guts to lay this out. Maybe a person who was not popular and was declined for something not related to the rubber stamp passage of these disability cases.

replies.commentBody: It is reasonable to assume there are patterns in MC judgments that should be watched in an overall effort to mitigate fraud claims. But, then we know that the watchmen are also schemers… It's a horrible shame.

comments.commentBody: I used to work as a Disability Adjudicator.  It's not a clerical job but requires a fair amount of experience and education.  The Social Security rules are complex and, in some cases, byzantine, so it takes awhile to get the hang of it.  I wish it were as simple as using facts, good judgment and common sense when deciding on claims but sadly, it sometimes isn't.  A great deal of weight in allowing or denying claims can come from the Medical Consultants (MCs) and, particularly, from both the Consulting Examiner (the psychiatrist or psychologist who does a consultative exam on the claimant) as well as the MCs (these are docs who work directly for Social Security, reviewing the claim, including medical records).  In addition, decisions can be reversed at appeals level by a judge.  Thus, the system itself can produce results that an individual has a difficult time mitigating -- especially when inaccurate medical advice is given. The system sort of has a life of its own. In some cases, a whole claim can hinge on a report from one psychiatrist. Medical records do play a part, but with lack of evidence the consultative exam can play a large role (thus, the emphasis put on coaching these NYPD schemers to fool the psychiatrists). The "clerks" who you refer to -- actual adjudicators who oversee the medical portion of claim from beginning to end -- have their hands tied when an MC overrules their analysis of the claim.

Doesnt' some culpability lie with the clerks and political appointees at SSDI?

Don't they ever check the veracity of these claims, or do they simply rubber stamp (a l a former Long Island Railroad employees disability claims) these claims?
Downton Abbey educational? That's a good one. It's rubbish on every level.
Sure it's a TV show but Ms. Dowd has a point. What would not be tolerated in modern domestic politics is embraced on TV. DA is just soft porn for Anglophiles.
It `s like "The American Dream"---it `s a farce.

Oh for heaven's sake. It's a TV show. We watch dramas about murderers, about dysfunctional families, about failed folksingers, about wars past and present.
We also watch dramas about princes avenging the death of their father at their uncle's hands, or star-crossed lovers whose love ends in suicide.
It's not because we like these things and want to have more of them. It's because the dramas are entertaining or educational or cathartic or conscience-catching.
Get a life, Maureen.

John, I hang out a lot with folks in their 20s (i'm in a rock crowd), and these folks are not innocent the way people were before the 80s and the internet.
They know so much more than we did then.

Yes, they still have the innocence of youth, thank God, but it is so different.
Let Rick Perry foot this one, personally.
Yes, Texas is so willing to support single parents. The state of Texas only seems interested in babies when they are in utero - after they are born, they don't seem to care too much.
Unbelievable.  Let the public hospital and the state of Texas pay to care for this child, if she can even survive, for her entire life.

@Patrick:

Bob Dylan never said anything of the kind. If Dylan said it then prove me wrong and post the attribution as per any half reliable source.

You are confusing something you wish Dylan had said with the old adage first propounded by Abraham Lincoln: "You can fool all the people some of the time, and some of the people all the time, but you cannot fool all the people all the time."

By making up that Dylan quote you've severely undercut the credibility of the anecdotes in your own post above. You really ought to heed Lincoln's sage observation.
More rationalization from this retired officer. Your union and membership knew, on some level, colleagues who game the system. And the system is ripe for gaming. Pickings for all!

What evidence do any of you have for non-viability? There is criticism for the hospital making choices,  and politicians yet you sound hypocritical making your own moral judgement like it has more weight.  All without hard data of the unborn child. Do you have a medical degree and have you seen the babys charts? Should I stand behind the medical profession or the self-righteous culture of our time.  Just because you want or feel doesn't make it right. If you can stand behind gay and lesbians, why not an unborn baby who is just as valuable?  The government wastes way more than the cost of this baby and adoption is cheap. She would have had the child if this had not happened so he would be a single dad.  Isn't he anyway?  His insurance comes from the government as a firefighter.  I hope your life is worth more than an assigned value made up by someone across the country.

I view the hospital's actions, based upon their interpretation of the state law, as a true perversion of medical care and compassion.  The description of this case reminds me of horrific science fiction stories in which human beings are produced in artificial, non-animate pods.  That is exactly what the state and hospital have turned Mrs. Munoz's body into - an inanimate pod for developing a non-viable fetus.

My experience from observation (and why I didn't sue):
The hospital is big and rich. You are small and poor. They can draw on endless resources. You have Legal Aid, maybe. They will lawyer, subpoena, deposition, and delay you into the ground. The fairy stories of the OT notwithstanding, Goliath always wins.
Sue the hospital. NOW.

Eric, you're ony partly right.  Conservatives don't want government to interfere with our lives - but only if you're male. If you're female, then you obviously don't have the good sense to know what's good for you, or what you want, and politicians (male politicians at that) need to do the thinking for you.
Well put. No regard for human suffering, it's all in the heads of politicians - and church leaders.

Barbaric.  Clearly, Texas politicians have made policy without regard for the human suffering these policies are inflicting on people.  It's all in their heads, and has nothing to do with real life, real people, and the realities of life and death.  May peace be with the family who are bearing the brunt of this craziness.

This shows so clearly how wrong the right wing extremists are in this country. They have no sense of humanity or compassion or anything.

I do not understand why this is, but It is disgusting.

troublemaker,

So you think the baby deserves capital punishment? Of what crime was the baby convicted?

ECL -

What "baby"? This is only a fetus. Your deliberate use of such terminology is based on your personal need to ignore human biology and the meaning of time to try to equate potential human life with actual life. That basic moral and scientific misconception, and your forcing it upon others, is simply detestable and wrong.

Look, the rest of us understand the importance of time on potential life, just like the Court did in Roe v. Wade. But you are reversing the meaning of time and human biology.

The woman is/was an actual human individual already and retains the basic right to a dignified end, to the greatest extent possible. Your view and terminology is just gross ignorance and superstition, supporting the most inhuman and inhumane behavior imaginable by Texas and the hospital. A horror show.

@ EC-  Do you really think it's kinder to make the child be born, only to suffer?  The mother was reportedly deprived of oxygen for a long period of time (up to an hour), according to the doctors.  There's pretty much NO chance the baby will be born healthy, and a very high chance that it will suffer from significant medical problems for the rest of its life.  Is that compassionate?

The State of Texas or any state (including the state of insanity) should mind their own business and let this poor family grieve for this unfortunate dead woman.  As for the "interests" of the fetus, Texas should become far less interested, and perhaps get to the business of running the remainder of the state, which is in far more dire need.

The old adage, "If you work hard, you will succeed," does not apply to this generation.

Ten years ago, I saw interns getting hired before they could finish their internships. Now... they have trouble getting real jobs in their industry years after they graduate... with higher debt for student loans than ever.

I also want to add... this cutting off of benefits doesn't just affect the person being cut off. In a city like NY, I had a roommate (one of seven I had in my first five years here) who lost her job and bounced two rent checks, which I eventually had to pay to the landlord on her behalf because I was the name on the lease, and she literally had nothing in the bank to cover it, and her family couldn't help. When the government cuts off benefits to one person in an apartment, they affect everyone living with the person--family or not. As a full-time worker, it still put me into debt that took me a year and a half to dig out of, because I was only just barely making ends meet myself, and she obviously couldn't pay her utilities either (which I also covered so I didn't destroy my credit rating--you can't put 3 people on a utility bill, even if 3 unrelated people live in that apartment.)

The ripple effect is harsh, because when you cut someone off from benefits, and they can't get a job, the people around them in their same economic class suffer too--friends, family, roommates.

It wasn't her fault, but her bad financial situation almost took me down too.
How to pay for it?  End million dollar "subsidies" for billionaire farmers, for a start.
Thank you for a well-balanced report. I found it fascinating.

I disagree.  I think, on balance, there's nothing (good) to be said for having a titled aristocracy.  Do you believe that a titled aristocracy and the Koch brothers-like conspiracy are mutually exclusive?  I'll see your Koch brothers and raise you a Murdoch.

Pluralism in Saudi Arabia?  Please.  Women can't drive cars by themselves.  Shi'ia are the apostates.  Pluralism?  That means democracy which is an alien word to a family that owns the whole peninsula save a few enclaves of fellow Sunnis in the Gulf and Yemen, the training ground for Al Qaeda.  Pluralism in Saudi Arabia.  That's like Postal Service (an oxymoron).

I think that the Saudis should read Mr. Friedman today on the need to develop pluralism in the Arab world and then they could convince Bashir Assad to resign and to allow pluralism in Syria or that he should allow pluralism and all would be forgiven.
Or perhaps Mr. Friedman should have read this article before writing about the need for pluralism in the Middle East.
The Saudis would not even understand the issue of pluralism. It is the forces of evil against the forces of lesser or more evil, all by proxy-until it is in your backyard, then it is the forces of good- and it is religious and tribal and ethnic and as long as the Saudis bankroll the rebels, and why quibble over minutiae, then it could go on for decades, and indeed the CIA in public pronouncements have given this a decade.
While some on both sides, near and far, might have temporary pangs of conscience, these soon dissipate in the face of religious-tribal and ethnic imperatives.

All that one has to remember about salafist Saudis is "September 11". All the terrorists were Saudi, with the exact same type of thinking and background as these so called rebels in Syria. Who is backing them? Saudi princes & government with their billions of dollars in petrodollars. Have the US government & the world already forgotten about what these Al Qaeda salafists are capable of doing?
Saudi royals are using Iran as an excuse in full support to these killers who know no morality. It will be a monumental disaster if the western governments will not reign in on the Saudis to change their behavior.
Saudi Arabia has been & is the main source of all terrorism. Al Qaeda is made in Saudi Arabia. The world should wake up.

@a. pankin:  I hope everyone who wants to live in FL goes there and doesn't come back, because it will free up space in NY - and in the long run those people will find out just how badly FL treats older people.  And then it'll be too late to come back to NY!

You're mistaken. Look up a feature by NPR planet Money 'Disability in America". In fact if you hire a lawyer, it is VERY EASY to get disability to get approved: and that is exactly what these folks did.
As an academic physician, I see questionable cases on a regular basis and refuse to sign the papers if I dont think the patient is truly disabled.

----------- the fireguys routinely check themselves into the emergency room after being called out to a fire (ANY fire ) with the claim that they inhaled toxic smoke.   this just sets the basis for claiming disability later on . . .
I can see your point but a person who claims disability on the basis of 'incapacitating back pain" shouldn't be jet skiing.....
